Game: Downfall
Genre: Psychological Horror Adventure
Developer: Harvester Games
Publisher: Screen 7
Copy supplied by developer

Downfall is a psychological horror adventure game developed by Harvester Games and published by Screen 7, the same people behind 2012's The Cat Lady. This is a remake of the 2009 game by the same developers, and it is included in this version.

STORYYou play as Joe Davis, a man who goes on vacation with his wife Ivy to the Quiet Haven hotel to try and fix their marriage problems. However, after the first night, Ivy disappears and weird, disturbing, violent and space-bending things start to happen.
If you played the developer's previous game or read some of Stephen King's horror novels, you know what you are gonna get: a creepy and weird story with depressed characters and dark humor. Saying more about the story would spoil it, but just know this: I was hooked from the get-go and I played the entire game in one sitting, which rarely happens to me. I laughed, I cringed, and I even cried while playing this. One of the best stories in a game since Telltale's first season of The Walking Dead.

GRAPHICSThe game is made with Adventure Game Studio, and you will either love or hate how it looks. It's mostly in black and white with 2D stripes and burst of colors (mostly a lot of red blood). There are some disturbing and gory images that might scar those who aren't used to them, and a couple of sequences will leave you with your eyes wide open in sheer terror.

GAMEPLAYThe game is played entirely with the keyboard. You can pick up, examine and use items, as well as talk to the people that you will find. It is a very standard adventure game and there isn't any sequence that changes things up a bit, but the game focuses more on the story rather than gameplay, and the latter works more than well to move the story forward.

CHALLENGEThe puzzle are usually really intuitive and even non-fans of the genre won't have trouble figuring out what to do. Still, I would've liked a couple more thought-provoking puzzles than the ones that we got.

SOUNDThe voice acting is either going to ruin or make your experience. I personally really enjoyed it: the voice actors deliver their lines in a weird way that, surprisingly, works with the overall tone of the movie. I also really enjoyed the soundtrack that mixes quiet and eerie tracks with hard-rock songs.

REPLAYABILITYThere are many choices that you make in the game that will change the outcome, leading to one of three different endings. There are also 30 Steam achievements to unlock that will keep you completionists busy enough to play the game at least three times.

Overall, Downfall is an incredible adventure game that delivers a compelling, eerie and romantic story with simple but effective gameplay, delightfully weird voice acting and good replayability. A must-buy for fans of great stories in video games!

reviewText:
As far as psychological horrors go there may not be many better games released in 2016 than Harvester Games’ Downfall. This shouldn’t be a surprise to those of you who are aware with the studio’s work given the outstanding The Cat Lady that the studio released in 2012. Despite releasing only last month the original version of the game was released even before The Cat Lady in 2009. The original 2009 release of the game is now freeware which you can get from the title’s official website.

For those of you who are questioning whether or not you should just grab the free game or to pony up the $13.99 for the newly released version do know that the recently released version has been significantly remade and has been reimagined in a fashion similar to that of The Cat Lady – which to fans of the game should automatically raise a huge smile. For those unaware of the original title then I’d like to kindle your imagination with the thoughts of some of the best psychological horrors on the big screen coming to mind in 1408  and Identity.

I was a huge fan of the controls that are established within the game. The simplicity of the system makes the game a joy to play and allows the player to concentrate on the story being narrated. I’m not going to spoiler the game too much as it is another game that deserves to be played and experienced first hand. I know some of you have advised me that you consider it lazy writing but I firmly believe that there are just some games that demand to be experienced first hand rather than being narrated to you to the point where when you come to play the game it becomes impossible for the narrative to have the same effect upon you as it possibly could have.

The graphics while simple really help establish the atmosphere and aide immersion. The camera work is extraordinary and while I know Total Biscuit hates people referring to games as cinematic experiences this is certainly a game that deserves that phrase being applied to it. Animations are used sparingly but when they are used in each scene there is an undeniable purpose which is consistently well executed. The decisions made towards the utilization of monochrome with very minimal utilization of color is outstanding and extend through to the lighting used throughout the game. This makes the horror and the gore stand out at a level that is arguably greater than the sum of its parts. This in turn leads to the voice acting. Although there are some scenes that I feel lack the oomph that would have made it a truly great experience throughout there is enough strength in the delivery that makes the whole above average. The decisions behind the choice of songs that constitute soundtrack are also of a sound decision. The sounds again raise the level of the horror and demand praise. It is a game that I would recommend that you wear headphones for.

A word of warning for some of you to take heed of is that there is quite a significant amount of gore throughout the game.

Downfall is one of the best psychological horror experiences I have enjoyed across all media in a long time. It is highly recommended.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Polish developer Remigiusz Michalski in 2009 introduced an interesting adventure Downfall, which was praised for its horror atmosphere with intriguing story. It is now published in its revised version, which every obscure adventure games fan should not miss.

Downfall was inherently point and click adventure, but in a revised version this is more of an interactive story in the style of Telltale Games. The author left the classic point and click interface, completely redesigned graphics and music, let the dub characters (one character is dubbed by a fan of the previous games) and even rewrote the story to partially follow a different game The Cat Lady to please its fans. Remake is thus not only a newly released version of the game.

The first major change and the hallmark of the game is that the environment of the camera is viewed from the side, and the main protagonist is controlled directly via the keyboard. In essence, therefore using only the keyboard. The game does not use the mouse at all, and after a while you will find that playing with just one hand is so easy. Backgrounds are a mix of photographs, rendered 3D models and cartoon characters. Today's players might argue that the game is graphically outdated, but according to me it is a raw and original visual concept that somehow belongs to Downfall.

The graphical representation is related to a story that certainly does not mince words and warnings at the beginning of the game, that this is a game for adults. After the opening sequence, where we introduce the main characters Joe and Ivy reveals, that among them there is something wrong. Couple arrives at Quiet Haven to spend the night. Ivy starts to behave strangely and soon lost. If you expect it will be a classic horror plot about kidnapped mistress and some monster holding her, you are far from the core. In fact, it is a very thoughtful psychological horror that you’ll be thinking about even after finishing. Downfall is not afraid to dish out some very gory scenes and two rather gross tasks. Additionally, it is often possible to choose dialogue options available in a journey, which then leads to a different end. There’s no need to spoil anything, but Downfall offers more than just one conclusion.

The puzzles are well designed and items needed to solve them are in sequential order as the narrative goes. You could say that their difficulties are among the simple, basically it is impossible to be stuck on something. Here it's all about the story. Fans will be pleased that the story includes some characters from other author’s games and it looks like it is going to be a sequel.

The only drawback is the use of already aged Adventure Game Studio engine, where you can’t simply change the game resolution from the standard 800 × 600 pixels, for example, on a notebook. It’s a pity author didn’t use some advanced engine.

Overall this game caught me with its story and stylisation that I basically finished it in one sitting during the evening. It has achievements on Steam that reveal a few surprises, so playing time is extended. If you are into dark and unusual adventure games, I definitely have to recommend a new version of Downfall.

reviewText:
If Quentin Tarantino ever made a video game, it would be this game.
It's gory, surreal, and so very, very messed up... and I love it.

Downfall is a psychological horror game, and the gameplay mechanics are pretty simple. Everything you do, you do with the arrow keys. You find items, put them in your inventory, and use them to solve puzzles (which are pretty simple) However, the most important factor in this game is the story. And boy, what a story it is.

The game is very short, it will take you approximately 4-5 hours to finish - and that's if you're being thorough. Now, usually I would recommend picking up games of this length on a sale, this one however I think it's worth the full price. The replayability value in this game is insane. So many dialogue options and scenarios, and there are 3 possible endings. The good, the bad and the neutral. Though, the good isn't really all that happy either. Which I liked!

The good stuff
* Dialogue - the script for this game is amazing. It's worth playing just for Joe's mean lines alone.
* Artstyle - very unique and surreal. Hell, even the paintings in this game are great! Gloomy and dark with hints of color (red) throughout the game.
* Soundtrack - the maker of this game is very good at choosing the right music for each scenario. I love all the soundtracks, and I find myself listening to them outside of the game as well. Really helps creating the atmosphere.
* Replayability - I highly recommend taking your time to explore all the dialogue and all the outcomes. Will take you approximately 12-15 hours.
* Puzzles - not too easy, not too obvious either. Clever.
* Story - the story will mess with your head. It's weird, and I love it.
* Price - good price for an amazing game.
* Joe Davis - yep.

The not-so-good stuff
* Audio - sometimes the audio just sounds... off. Some of the voice actors have a really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ mic, which sorta ruins the mood and dialogue sometimes. This was a problem The Cat Lady had as well.
* Sometimes the controls feels slow and not responsive. Also a problem The Cat Lady had.

I highly recommend playing this, especially if you're already a Cat Lady fan. Those of you with a BBW fetish might enjoy this as well.

reviewText:
This experience was horrifying. Of all the gore and overt attempts at disgust that games and movies deal with these days, only few are truly effective. In games you are either stopped entirely and put into a cutscene of some kind or you face these horrors with obliviousness, whereby the characters does not even to what we know he or she must be aware of, and that conventionally horrify you. Downfall has an interesting movement in this regard, it falls somewhere between the loss of control of a cutscene, but within the world of the played character. A loss of control in this sense is what we in real life would call a reflexive reaction. We cringe, brace ourselves, shield our face, eyes, cower back, etc, and the same happens in this game. This is one part of the realism that underlies the entirety of this experience. And it is that same realism that manages to hit so hard, and actually horrify as every absurdly surrealistic scene has roots to the physical world; yet becomes otherworldly in the compound of these worldly parts.

When I wrote about The Cat Lady, I mistakenly called it fittingly ugly. This was largely due to an inability to thoughtfully articulate what actually went on aesthetically in games of this ilk (only Downfall and The Cat Lady, as far as I know). Ugliness in regards to this game should entirely be replaced with the term unsettling, or uncanny. It is ugly in the sense that dissonance is ugly. It is jarring, but that does not necessarily mean that it is not suitable for the purposes at hand. In horror, the discordant, unsettling and dissonant are vital to engender a creepy atmosphere.

But Downfall falls far beyond the merely creepy, and actually lands in the sphere of horror, actual horror. And rarely with much pretense or by having disgust be the goal in and of itself, Downfall's disgust, conjured by the various scenes, serve a narrative purpose; they more often than not carry a symbolic value. This is in large due to the psychological aspect. Instead of straight up depression, as in The Cat Lady, Downfall instead deals with eating disorders or general self-hatred, basically dysmorphobia, where one has either a delusional or actual flaw that is exaggerated to the point of pathology. And it is this dysmorphic view that leads Joe Davis down this horrific path in his attempt to save his beloved wife, and the base which gives meaning to what you'd otherwise interpret as meaninglessly disgusting and surreal. Everything hearkens back to mental illness, allusions to schizophrenia and depression are as common as the dysmorphobia, and all add to the theme of the game, which I'd sum up as  the fight against the thoughts produced by mental illnesses, viz., our internal pathological struggles.

Along those lines the game struts. It flaunts its horror without being hemmed by shame, comfort nor laziness. But what does it have to say about beating these thoughts? Anything beyond the clichés? The dark room of the hateful thoughts about oneself are said to be counteracted by company, by appealing to the other. At the same time, as the other, we are told it is hopeless (depending on your actions in game, really, but this was the case for me). The multiple endings all add to the aforementioned realism, but vary in what they propound about the hopelessness of the ill mind, making the experience fragmented, divergent, depending on who you are and how you approach this topic, or these suffering people.

The choices of this game are somewhat subtle. And your actions are free in a sense, and it is hard to predict the consequences of these actions without playing the game multiple times. In a way that gives you replay value, but also a limited first-time experience. I prefer a one-time holistic experience. I do not necessarily think more time played means more value. But real choice, in games, are considered to be those that in some way affect the story or change the final outcome, and on that note, the choices in this game are real choices. But for those who do not necessarily want to play a game 4-5 times to exhaust all the options available to them, it becomes a source of frustration. However, I imagine the latter kind of people are a minority.

While there are puzzle elements, they are rarely problematic. It's a matter of simple world association and paying attention to the dialog and at times the dialog options. Explore thoroughly and pay attention and nothing should be too difficult to overcome in this game. This can be construed as both a positive and a negative, there is no challenge, really, but there is also no frustration. The horror gets to play its part without having to be compromised by overly complicated puzzles. And despite there being no real challenge, there is satisfaction in figuring out the solutions of the quandaries of Joe and company.

It's a concise experience. It is genuine and simple in many ways, but it serves the purpose of making the symbolic relations shine so much brighter. It's clear, most of all. The equivocalness that may arise is not due to any fault in the game's ability to tell a story, but in the story itself and what it tries to portray, which tend towards equivocalness. Attempting to do this is very much admirable. To touch darkness as a sort of exuberant catharsis. To with your full body delve into absolute horror and see your way through it. Mainly because you are an observer, thereby excluded from it, but also by playing a character going through it, sometimes managing, sometimes not. Instead of alluding to psychological pathology as a pretext for silliness or surrealism, it is used with a great understanding of its reality. The imagery is forceful to signify the intensity of the feeling not everyone experiences, but can through this game. This game can intensify our understanding of these mental issues, or at least give us the blueprint of what such a game could look like. Because it can be done more smoothly, I imagine, with greater focus on inner experience in lieu of the focus on a flashy narrative. We can stay in the moment, in the atmosphere of an awful inner life, Silent Hill 2, along with games like Downfall and The Cat Lady, proved that. But what they have yet to figure out is how to truly create a game where everything leads to the same place, like in Spec Ops: The Line, for example. These games on emotional pain have yet to figure out a way to fully encapsulate themselves in their thematics; yet they remain on a very interesting path towards excellent game-creation, that eventually will have the added bonus of being truly emotionally fulfilling, profound and beautiful.

I was a huge fan of both The Cat Lady and the original Downfall, especially in how they fit together and the world that was created. When I heard Downfall was being remade I was super psyched, and now it's finally out! Just finished my first runthrough, and I'm so pleased with this new version.

Good
-Voice acting! A little awkward in some places, but generally good. Shoutout to Chiseleya especially! Also a few familiar voices show up, and it was lovely to hear them.
-Clearer, more streamlined plot, including integration with TCL.
-The least intuitive puzzles/least fun segments of the original Downfall were removed or altered.
-Even though I knew the plot of the game and generally what was coming, there were surprises and some moments were still genuinely scary.
-TCL lovers will be extra, unexpectly pleased in the latter portion of the game.

Bad
-Short! I finished in about five hours I think, but I also generally knew how to solve the puzzles/where to progress the plot from the original Downfall so it may be longer for others.
-Answers a lot of previous questions about integration with TCL, but raises some new confusing ones. Maybe it'll make more sense the next play, though.
-A few classic awesome elements of the original Downfall ended up scrapped or altered.
-The plot might be a little TOO in your face and easy to understand now.

In general, I absolutely loved it and I'm looking forward to some more playthroughs. I'm definitely not disappointed with this remake, and even better it's different enough from the original that there's still replayability for both versions. Absolutely awesome.

reviewText: Downfall was one of my most hyped up releases of the past year or so, as I carry a certain fondess for the original 2009 version and The Cat Lady. After having played it, I can say that it was worth the hype, as the gameplay, soundtrack, characters and setting are all fantastic and tons of fun to soak in.\n\nHowever, be wary: the voice acting in this game is a teensy bit forced and, as much as I don't want to say it, amateurish (any time a certain character yells, you can hear their voice echo in the room they recorded it in, for example) and the plot can be difficult to describe and keep interest in. Aside from those points, though, Downfall is a great horror adventure game that feels more dynamic and involved than TCL, but less gripping and emotional.

reviewText:
Immediate impressions were terrible. Horrible voice acting and boring gameplay that feels more like doing chores than solving puzzles. I was ready to write this game off as laughable...

But I toughed it out and finished the game, and let me tell you it was worth it. The jump in quality from the start to finish of the game is MASSIVE. For all the missteps the game takes, it manages to do just enough things right to make the journey worth it.

There is certainly enough content to warrant to price tag, my first playthrough was about six hours, and there are a good number of endings to keep you coming back...

...but its hard to come back to a game that starts this slow, with unskippable dialouge that will test your patience to see more than one ending.

TL:DR Downfall was worth playing, but will certainly test what you're willing to put up with in a video game. I'm ready to start The Cat Lady next.

reviewText:
Downfall can be enjoyed as a remake/retelling of the original 2009 version, as a sequel to The Cat Lady or as a stand-alone game.  There are nods and allusions to both the original and TCL, but you honestly don’t have to be familiar with either one to play this game.  All the background information you need is given in the prologue; heck, you don’t even get this much in the original Downfall—it simply begins with a husband and wife seeking shelter from the storm in a hotel in the country.

If you’ve played The Cat Lady, you know what to expect in terms of graphics, sounds and gameplay.  The game’s color palette is almost exclusively black, white and red.  There’s voice acting! (More on that later.)  The interface is simple and easy-to-use with the names of objects you can interact with appearing on the screen whenever you walk passed them.  I’m not in the best position to judge the difficulty of the puzzles, having played the original Downfall in which many of the puzzles are the same, but I think they are easy, with clues that more-or-less tell you what to do whenever the solution isn’t obvious.  I’d say the difficulty level is lower than TCL.  Probably the designer wants players to enjoy the story that unfolds rather than getting stuck and spending a lot of time wandering around the hotel in search of what to do next.  I would have enjoyed some more challenging puzzles though; it’s a bit like one of those games where puzzles seem designed to keep you from getting ahead of yourself (e.g. you can’t get through this door until you find object X which is in the room where you meet Mary and that is because we want you to talk to Mary first).  In addition to the inventory based puzzles, you lead your character, Joe, through some conversations and places where he has to make choices.  These can affect the ending of the game.
I’d give the voice acting an 8.5/10.  For the most part I really liked it (I especially liked the voice of Joe, the protagonist), but there are some places where the voice actors make an odd choice on which word to emphasize (this is a pet peeve of mine); also Joe often speaks lines softly where it seems natural that he would raise his voice.

OK, I am a big fan of Downfall 2009 so I’m really aching to discuss my feelings about the differences between the remake and the original (And, hey, it’s included in the bundle so you can play both of them).  Some minor spoilers ahead…
* Some background regarding Joe’s childhood that we don’t get until the very end of DF2009 is expanded and moved to the prologue here—I thought this announced right away that this was going to be a new take on the story.
* I like how the Queen of Maggots is changed so her nature is more consistent with what we learn in TCL.
* I prefer the twist ending in the remake to the one in the original.  It fits better tonally with the rest of the game and it is set up more, so it doesn’t seem to come out of nowhere.
* Joe and Ivy’s relationship is developed more here and its changed some from DF2009.  I suppose it’s handled more maturely, it’s a more cohesive story and Ivy’s problems are more relatable.  That said, I miss the flashback with Lucifer in the bathroom.  I also miss the psychotic episode Ivy seems to be having when they first arrive at the hotel in DF2009 (screaming, seeing things).  In DF2009 it’s implied, at least at first, that this is a source of their relationship issues, but the problems they face in the remake are, I guess, more in keeping with the game’s theme.
* I really miss Joe’s descent into madness and (at least potentially) evil in DF2009.  I remember loving the dark choices he needs to make throughout the game.  Here his interactions with Sophie are less intense.  In the original he says at one point that she deserves a more painful death(!), and I really miss the extra ingredient you have to add to the smoothie recipe.  Maybe this is just me, second time through DF2009 I decided to play Joe as a total a-hole.
* In addition to thinking the developer might have a swung a bit too far in the opposite direction when it comes to the puzzles (eliminating some, giving the player big hints for others), I actually miss the chase scenes in DF2009.  They added a level of fear and exhilaration.

So that’s my 2 cents.  I would definitely recommend this game for its story, graphics and atmosphere and the multiple endings lend it replay value.  My one criticism is that, partly because of the lack of difficult puzzles, the game is on the short side.  It took me about 4 hours to complete it.

A fascinating game for all fans of horror. Using the already familiar art themes specific to The Cat Lady, the game bolsters the great idea of the original game into a true refined masterpiece. Unlike the original, the gameplay and puzzles are actually pretty intuitive here, with one or two small exceptions. Expect some gruesome and disturbing scenes and puzzles.
Using round, interesting or even mysterious characters, the game builds an emotional and often quite shocking story which will keep you gripped most of the time.
Apart from the obvious choices, some aren't that intuitive, so don't be surprised if you're left wandering what you did wrong when you get an ending different than expected.

The game is definitely recommended for everyone fascinated by horror or who simply enjoys this sort of art. I wouldn't, however, recommend it for someone simply looking for an emotional or engaging story.

I'm reccomeding this because the original game is bundled with the remake. The remake made no sense and tried to hard to be the original instead of standing on it's own feet. Buy it on sale, not for full price like I did.
I played the original right before the remake and actually prefer everything about the original. The original actually had me gagging at some points and not wanting to continue because I knew what was about to happen. This remake had me wanting to finish so I could get to the cameos at the end and then left me wanting.
My main issue is the plot. The remake skewed the story so much it didn't even fit in with what we were shown in the Cat Lady. It kept the same events and motivations from the first game but updated them to try to make them fit into the new game and they didn't. Characters were not fleshed out enough for their actions to make sense. Like the fact they kept the axe man from the original but didn't offer an explanation for him and he wasn't used to his full advantage in my opinion. And then he suddenly poofs and isn't seen for the rest of the game.
Spoilers: In the original game, Sophie is trying to become fat for the man she loves and becomes morbidly obese. In this game, she's trying to become skinny but still has a recipe for a fattening smoothie?? And still ends up obese. Also her final incarnation has become demonic despite the remake never explaining why.  Ivy, in the original, doesn't eat so Joe feeds her to death and is revealed to be large at the end. When we see Joe and Ivy in the Cat Lady, Ivy is seen to be obese. In the remake Ivy is battling anorexia but when we are told about her true form at the end she is skin and bones, that Joe wasn't trying to save her, even though that's the whole point of the game. Also Ivy went from having mental problems in the first game to just being an unlikeable character with an attitude and a negative attitude about everyting.
The voice acting was not done well. There was not enough energy put into most of the characters. This made listening to them difficult and I wish there was an option to turn them off. I liked the cameos they included and when Agnes was around she was great to listen to. Everything was voiced, they never just had text on screen, which is something that I really appreciated.
In the original game you had to option to use the arrow keys to move or point and click your way around. This game used the same controls from the Cat Lady, arrow keys to do everything. It took a little getting used to but the inventory was easier to use in this style.
This was a well made game but for me there wasn't enough love put into it as there was in the original and I really wish they had either changed more or kept things more the same. Actions didn't make sense, the voice acting detracted from the experience, and movement was difficult to get used to. If you're looking for a new truly gruesome horror experience, I recommend the original. The remake is a different experience all it's own.

WARNING! Mild spoilers.

As a recovering anorexic, I really enjoyed this game. Anorexia is a highly misunderstood subject. The fact that it's actuall a mental illness, and a serious one at that, is hardly ever even brought up. Most portrayals of anorexia depict it as skinny girls not eating, no more than than. This game delves into the true horrors of the illness. The obsessions, the paranoia, and just how difficult it is to pull away. The way it was explained by the memory of Sophie in the room of mirrors was incredibly accurate. This game was clearly made by someone who understands eating disorders, and I really appreciated that.

Overall, gameplay was nice. It wasn't too long-- it only took me about an hour and a half to complete a single runthrough. The puzzles were fairly straightforward, but still provided a challenge. As in The Cat Lady, there's no real efficient way to move from place to place on the map (no quick transport, dashing, etc.), but the map isn't altogether too big. The plot was a bit nebulous at times. It was unclear what was meant to be real and what wasn't-- but maybe that was intentional, as a representation of Joe's mental illness. Confusing as is, the story was still very good, but all three endings were rather sad and dissatisfying, especially to fans of The Cat Lady. But horror games don't have to have happy endings, I suppose.

Taking everything into account, I'd strongly recommend this game. Worth the money for sure.

First of all I'd like to say I loved this game's art style and over all general feeling that it gave.  It was definitely a game that kept my attention (which believe me, is hard) and constantly kept me craving more the further I got into it.  The story itself was a good 8/10, and without giving away any spoilers, threw me for several loops.

Only real negative things I can say about this game is the voice acting for a few of the characters were pretty bad.  At times I had just wished it didn't have any voice acting at all.  It's hard to say though what rating I'd give the voice acting, because some of the people were actually really good, it's just there were a few bad apples in there that really kind of ruined some of the moments for me.  Also, the beginning of the game at times was a bit hard to follow.

Aside from that though, this game was very good and was a good 5-6 hours of entertainment just from one playthrough.  I have a feeling I'll play through this game again in the future to check out what happens if I try out some of the different options, because playing through it once only got me a very small chunk of the achievements.  The puzzles as well were very easy to follow if you used the game's logic to solve them, which is something a lot of games have a hard time doing right, and just come off as confusing and end up losing my interest.

TL;DR
+Good story
+Good puzzles
+Great artwork/style
+Good price for the amount of playability
+Great video game for people who make Let's Plays
-Bad voice acting at times
-Sometimes the game was a bit pixelated and stretched out looking (I'm not sure if I had the settings wrong though)

Check out the video attached to watch my genuine reactions to this game. :D
